page.title: List of minor Apogee Software video games

revisions.rev:
The following is a list of the earliest, lesser-known video games published by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]].
==Games== ===Beyond the Titanic===
{{Infobox VG|title=Beyond the Titanic |image= |developer=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |publisher=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |designer=[[Scott Miller (programmer)|Scott Miller]] |released=1986 |genre=[[Text adventure]] |modes=[[Single player]] |platforms=[[DOS]] |media=[[Floppy disk]] |input=Keyboard }} '''''Beyond the Titanic''''' is a [[text adventure]] game written by [[Scott Miller (programmer)|Scott Miller]] for [[DOS]], published by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]]. In the game, the player has to escape from the sinking ship ''[[RMS Titanic|Titanic]]''.
The game was originally distributed as [[shareware]]. It was one of the two games (the other being ''[[Supernova (computer game)|Supernova]]'') that were released by Apogee not using the Apogee Model, but as traditional shareware.
''Beyond the Titanic'' was re-released as [[freeware]] by Apogee to hang in on the hype around the [[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic movie]] on March 10, 1998. The source code for the game was released under [[GPL]] on March 20, 2009.<ref name="OldGamesFreeware">{{cite web |url=http://www.3drealms.com/news/2009/03/several_old_games_released_as_freeware.html |title=Several old games released as Freeware |accessdate=26 March 2009 |publisher=[[3DRealms]]}}</ref> See also [[list of commercial games released as freeware]].
{{-}}
===Star Trek: The Next Generation Trivia===
{{Infobox VG |title=Star Trek: The Next Generation Trivia |image= |developer=[[Micro F/X Software]] |publisher = [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |designer = [[George Broussard]] |released = {{vgrelease|NA=1987}} |genre = [[Educational game|Educational]] |modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms = [[DOS]] |media = [[Floppy disk]] |input = Keyboard }}
'''''Star Trek: The Next Generation Trivia''''' (also known as ''Next Generation Trivia'') is a trivia game about the [[Star Trek: The Next Generation]] TV series written for DOS, published by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]]. It was originally published by [[George Broussard]] under [[Micro F/X Software]], before he joined Apogee.
The game was distributed as [[shareware]]. It consists of three volumes (named Volume 1 to 3), with only the first volume distributed as shareware, and the rest available commercially. Each volume has 100 multiple choice questions related to Star Trek: The Next Generation.
When the Star Trek copyright holder [[CBS Paramount Television|Paramount]] found out Apogee was making money on their property, they offered Apogee a license to the game idea. Apogee did not accept the offer, as the license would have cost more than what Apogee was making on the game.<ref name="SieglerParamout">[http://forums.3drealms.com/vb/showthread.php?p=30108#post30108] Joe Siegler explains the rationale for not accepting a license agreement from Paramount</ref> Therefore, Apogee discontinued the game, and they no longer retain any copyright or control over on it.<ref name="NoCopyright">[http://www.3drealms.com/games.html] "We do not retain any copyright or control on the following titles: Star Trek Trivia, Star Trek: TNG Trivia, and Jumpman Lives! (which means we don't care what you do with these three games - we don't have anything to do with them anymore)."</ref>
{{-}}
===Supernova===
{{For|Stars! Supernova Genesis computer game|Stars!#Stars.21_Supernova_Genesis}}
{{Infobox VG|title=Supernova |image= |developer=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |publisher=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |designer=[[Scott Miller (programmer)|Scott Miller]] |released=1987 |genre=[[Text adventure]] |modes=[[Single player]] |platforms=[[DOS]] |media=[[Floppy disk]] |input=Keyboard }}
'''''Supernova''''' is a [[text adventure]] game written by [[Scott Miller (programmer)|Scott Miller]] for DOS, published by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]]. The story of the game was written by Scott Miller and [[Terry Nagy]].
The game was originally distributed as [[shareware]]. It was one of the two games (the other being ''[[Beyond the Titanic]]'') that were released by Apogee not using the Apogee Model, but as traditional shareware.
The [[Turbo Pascal]] 3.0 source code was for sale for $100.<ref>Supernova Instructions, 1998 freeware release</ref>
''Supernova'' was re-released as [[freeware]] by Apogee on March 10, 1998. The source code for the game was released under [[GPL]] on March 20, 2009.<ref name="OldGamesFreeware" /> See also [[list of commercial games released as freeware]].
{{-}}
===The Thor Trilogy===
{{Infobox VG| title=The Thor Trilogy |image= |developer=[[Scenario Software]] |publisher=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |designer=[[Todd Replogle]] |engine= |version= |released=1989 |genre=[[Maze]] |modes=[[Single player]] |ratings= |platforms=[[DOS]] |media=[[Floppy disk]] |requirements= |input=[[computer keyboard|Keyboard]] }} '''''The Thor Trilogy''''' (also known as ''Caves of Thor'') is a maze [[video game]] published in 1989 by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]]. It was developed by [[Todd Replogle]] under the [[Scenario Software]] name.
The game places the player trapped within the Caves of Thor. The object of the game is to locate three missing items scattered throughout the place. The missing items are the Female-item, the Heart-item and the Male-item. The game's interface, gameplay and graphics are similar to a previous Apogee game, [[Kroz series|Kingdom of Kroz]], and to the game [[ZZT]].
The game was originally distributed as [[shareware]]. It consists of three volumes, with only the first volume distributed as shareware, and the rest available commercially. The volumes are:
*Volume I: Caves of Thor *Volume II: Realm of Thor *Volume III: Thor's Revenge
The source code of the game used to be available for U$195.00 (in 1990) directly from Todd Replogle. The game was discontinued, and it was later re-released as [[freeware]] by Apogee in December 2005. See also [[list of commercial games released as freeware]].
The game includes [[PC speaker]] renditions of various [[classical music]] pieces, including [[Flight of the Bumblebee]] by [[Rimsky-Korsakov]], two preludes from the [[Well-Tempered Clavier]] by [[J.S. Bach]], and [[Solfeggietto]] by [[C.P.E. Bach]].
{{-}}
===Trek Trivia===
{{Infobox VG |title=Trek Trivia |image= |developer=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |publisher=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |designer=[[Scott Miller (programmer)|Scott Miller]] |released={{vgrelease|NA=1986}} |genre=[[Educational game|Educational]] |modes=[[Single-player video game|Single-player]] |platforms=[[DOS]] |media=[[Floppy disk]] |input=Keyboard }}
'''''Trek Trivia''''' is a trivia game about the [[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]] TV series, written in [[Turbo Pascal]] 5.0 for DOS, published by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] (now 3D Realms).
Trek Trivia was distributed as [[shareware]]. It consists of ten volumes (named Volume 1 to 10), with only the first volume distributed as shareware, and the rest available commercially. Each volume has 100 multiple choice questions related to Star Trek.
Programmers could buy the source code for $90, but later the price was increased to $100.
When the Star Trek copyright holder [[CBS Paramount Television|Paramount]] found out Apogee was making money on their property, they offered Apogee a license to the game idea. Apogee did not accept the offer, as the license would have cost more than what Apogee was making on the game.<ref name="SieglerParamout" /> Therefore, Apogee discontinued the game, and they no longer retain any copyright or control over on it.<ref name="NoCopyright"/>
{{-}}
===Trivia Whiz===
{{Infobox VG| title = Trivia Whiz |image = |developer = [[Micro F/X Software]] |publisher = [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |designer = [[George Broussard]] |released = 1988 |genre = [[Educational game]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[DOS]] |media = [[Floppy disk]] |input = Keyboard }} '''''Trivia Whiz''''' is a general trivia game written for DOS, published by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]]. It was originally published by [[George Broussard]] under [[Micro F/X Software]], before he joined Apogee.
Trivia Whiz was distributed as [[shareware]]. It consists of five volumes (named Volume 1 to 5), with only the first volume distributed as shareware, and the rest available commercially. Each volume has 100 multiple choice questions on a large variety of topics.
The game was discontinued, and it was later re-released as [[freeware]] by Apogee in December 2005. See also [[list of commercial games released as freeware]].
{{-}}
===Word Whiz===
{{Infobox VG|title=Word Whiz |image= |developer=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |publisher=[[3D Realms|Apogee Software]] |designer=[[Scott Miller (programmer)|Scott Miller]] |released=1988 |genre=[[Educational game]] |modes=[[Single player]] |platforms=[[DOS]] |media=[[Floppy disk]] |input=Keyboard }} '''''Word Whiz''''' is a trivia game written for DOS, published by [[3D Realms|Apogee Software]]. It consists of various questions about different English words.
Word Whiz was distributed as [[shareware]]. It consists of four volumes (named Volume 1 to 4), with only the first volume distributed as shareware, and the rest available commercially. Each volume has 100 multiple choice questions, each one about a specific word.
Word Whiz is written in [[Turbo Pascal]] 5.0 and the source code was for sale for $100.
The game was discontinued, and it was later re-released as [[freeware]] by Apogee in December 2005. The source code for the game was released under [[GPL]] on March 20, 2009.<ref name="OldGamesFreeware" /> See also [[list of commercial games released as freeware]].
{{-}}
